ctrlnmod.models.ssmodels.continuous.general package

Submodules

ctrlnmod.models.ssmodels.continuous.general.gnssm module

class ctrlnmod.models.ssmodels.continuous.general.gnssm.GNSSM(nu, ny, nx, hidden_layers=[16], act_f='relu', out_eq_nl=False, alpha=None, bias=True, lin_model_type=None, lip=None, param='sqrtm', gamma=None, gamma2=None)[source]

Bases: SSModel

Class representing a Generalized Neural State-Space Model (GNSSM). ..math:

\dot{x} = Ax + Bu + f(x, u)
y = Cx + h(x)

where \(f\) and \(h\) are nonlinear functions approximated by neural networks. The linear part :math:`(A, B, C)`can be parameterized to have desired properties such as stability or finite gain.

Parameters:

  • nu (int)

  • ny (int)

  • nx (int)

  • hidden_layers (List[int])

  • act_f (str)

  • out_eq_nl (bool)

  • alpha (float | None)

  • bias (bool)

  • lin_model_type (str | None)

  • lip (dict[str, float] | None)

  • param (str)

  • gamma (float | None)

  • gamma2 (float | None)

nu

Number of inputs.

Type:

int

ny

Number of outputs.

Type:

int

nx

Number of states.

Type:

int

hidden_layers

List of hidden layer sizes for the neural networks.

Type:

List[int]

act_f

Activation function used in the neural networks (‘tanh’ or ‘relu’) default is ‘relu’.

Type:

str

out_eq_nl

Whether to include a nonlinear output equation.

Type:

bool

alpha

Maximum decay rate for the linear part (A) (default is None, which means no decay constraint).

Type:

Optional[float]

bias

Whether to include bias terms in the neural networks.

Type:

bool

linmod

a submodule representing the linear part it can be parameterized

Type:

Module

clone()[source]

Clone the model, it has to be implemented to be compliant with simulator classes.

Return type:

GNSSM

forward(u, x, d=None)[source]

Forward pass of the GNSSM.

Parameters:

  • u (Tensor) – Input tensor.

  • x (Tensor) – State tensor.

  • d (Tensor, optional) – Disturbance tensor. Defaults to None.

Returns:

Derivative of the state. y (Tensor): Output tensor.

Return type:

dx (Tensor)

init_weights_(A0, B0, C0, requires_grad=True, init_type='linear', margin=0.1)[source]

This method enables to initialize the weights it is both a wrapper for irght_inverse and the not parameterized weights of the module

Parameters:

init_type (str)

to_lure()[source]

Returns the Lur’e representation of the GNSSM: ẋ = Ax + B2 u + B1 φ(q) y = C2 x + D22 u + D21 φ(q) z = C1 x + D12 u + D11 φ(q) where φ(q) is the stacked nonlinear activation vector.

Return type:

Tuple[Tensor, ...]

class ctrlnmod.models.ssmodels.continuous.general.renode.DissipativeRENODE(nu, ny, nx, nq, sigma, Q, S, R, alpha=0.0, epsilon=0.0001, bias=False, feedthrough=True, out_eq_nl=False, param=None, device=device(type='cpu'))[source]

Bases: ContractingRENODE

This is a dissipative REN. It is a contractive REN satisfying a dissipation inequality given by the matrices QSR.

Parameters:

  • nu (int)

  • ny (int)

  • nx (int)

  • nq (int)

  • sigma (str)

  • Q (Tensor)

  • S (Tensor)

  • R (Tensor)

  • alpha (float)

  • epsilon (float)

  • bias (bool)

  • feedthrough (bool)

  • out_eq_nl (bool)

  • param (str | None)

  • device (device)

check()[source]

Check if the network satisfies the QSR dissipation inequality.

Returns:

True if the network satisfies the inequality, False otherwise.

Return type:

bool

forward(u, x)[source]

Forward pass of the model. This method should be implemented by subclasses. :type u: Tensor :param u: Input tensor. :type u: Tensor :type x: Tensor :param x: State tensor. :type x: Tensor :param d: Disturbance tensor. Defaults to None. :type d: Tensor, optional

Returns:

Output tensor.

Return type:

Tensor

Parameters:

  • x (Tensor)

class ctrlnmod.models.ssmodels.continuous.general.GNSSM(nu, ny, nx, hidden_layers=[16], act_f='relu', out_eq_nl=False, alpha=None, bias=True, lin_model_type=None, lip=None, param='sqrtm', gamma=None, gamma2=None)[source]

Bases: SSModel

Class representing a Generalized Neural State-Space Model (GNSSM). ..math:

\dot{x} = Ax + Bu + f(x, u)
y = Cx + h(x)

where \(f\) and \(h\) are nonlinear functions approximated by neural networks. The linear part :math:`(A, B, C)`can be parameterized to have desired properties such as stability or finite gain.

  • ny (int)

  • nx (int)
